Effects of nano-enabled agricultural strategies on food quality: Current knowledge and future research needs

Highlights
 Nano-enabled agrochemicals reduce environmental impacts of agricultural production  Nanofertilizers may increase food production and induce changes in produce ionome  Engineered nanomaterials may change protein content in plant-derived food  Effects on humans of produce from plants exposed to nanoagrochemicals are un-
known
Abstract
It is becoming more feasible to use nano-enabled agricultural products such as
nanofertilizers and nanopesticides to improve the efficiency of agrochemical delivery to crop plants. Experimental results have shown that nano-agrochemicals have great potential for reducing the environmental impact of traditional agrochemicals while simultaneously significantly increasing crop production. However, emerging data suggest that nano-enabled products are not only capable of increasing yield, but also result in alterations in crop quality. Variation in proteins, sugars, starch content, as well as in metallic essential elements have been reported. Verbi gratia, albumin, globulin, and prolamin have been significantly increased in rice exposed to CeO2 engineered nanoparticles (ENPs), while CeO2, CuO, and ZnO ENPs have increased Ca, Mg, and P in several crops. Conversely, reductions in Mo and Ni have been reported in cucumber and kidney beans exposed to CeO2 and ZnO engineered nanomaterials, respectively. However, reports on specific effects in human health due to the consumption of agricultural products obtained from plants exposed to nano-agrochemicals are still missing.
Keywords: Engineered nanomaterials, Nanofertilizers, Nanopesticides, Crop quality, Human health

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The literature suggests that the effects of engineered nanomaterials (ENMs) on crop
plants started to be evaluated about two decades ago. The first reports came from researchers working independently at different academic institutions and dealt mainly with toxicity studies. Several reports described effects of high concentration exposure on seed germination and seedling growth (Lu et al., 2002; Yang and Watts, 2005; Lin and Xing 2007). These studies, along with toxicity studies in other organisms, including humans, warned about the environmental risks of ENMs (Wiesner et al., 2006). In 2008, the US National Science Foundation (NSF) and the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) funded the creation of two big centers, the Center for Environmental Implications of Nanotechnology (CEINT), and the University of California Center for Environmental Implications of Nanotechnology (UC CEIN). These two centers generated outstanding information on hazard assessment at molecular, cellular and organismal level, as well as on the fate, transport, life cycle assessment, and toxicity of ENMs to terrestrial and marine organisms. Additionally, investigators at universities and research institutions worldwide dedicated numerous resources to exploring the effects of ENMs on living organisms, including plants. These efforts resulted in a robust literature collected in numerous review articles that have covered a span of almost two decades. Most of these reviews are discussed throughout this paper.
Studies on terrestrial plants have been mostly oriented towards studying the toxicological
impact of ENMs at the early stages of plant development. Most studies describe the effect of ENM exposure under controlled conditions with nutrient solutions as a feeding mechanism (Monica and Cremonini, 2009; Peralta-Videa et al., 2011). In 2010, a review article by Ma et al. (2010) described that some ENMs are taken up by the roots and subsequently translocated
Jo rn
al Pr
epr
oo f
through the plant body. On the other hand, Nair et al. (2010) offered several details about the possible use of ENMs in agriculture that include the delivery of genetic material, nutrients, and pesticides. In a review article by Gardea-Torresdey et al. (2014), it was reported that stable ENPs were observed in grains and leaves of agricultural plants (Figure 1). Gardea-Torresdey et al. (2014) also reported the transformation products accumulated in the aerial portion of the plants. The number of research and review articles about the use of ENMs in agricultural activities has steadily increased since then. A simple search in ScienceDirect.com using as keywords
“nanotechnology in agriculture,” shows that in the last 10 years; there has been high scientific
production on this topic including research and review articles, book chapters, and encyclopedia, among others (Figure 2). An analysis of the data shown in Figure 2 indicates that the total production of publications increased by 18% from 2017 to 2018 and 13% from 2018 to 2019. From the total production of 2017, 52% were research articles, 14% review articles, and 18% book chapters. In 2018, 53% were research articles, 17% review articles, and 18% book chapters. Whereas in 2019, there were 50% research articles, 16% review articles, and 23% book chapters. This suggests that total production of papers on this topic continues to increase with a similar distribution.
The most recent reviews on the interaction of ENMs with crop plants cover several topics.
For instance, Cappelli et al. (2020) suggest that ENMs can be used as sensors to detect heavy metals in potentially edible insects, and Kundu et al. (2019) indicate that ENMs may be used as sensors at pre-harvest and post-harvest stages. At pre-harvest, ENMs may help evaluate the nutritional status of plants, while at post-harvest, the nanosensors may help to monitor the shelflife of agricultural products. Other reviews emphasize the potential of ENMs as nanofertilizers (Adisa et al., 2019; Zulfikar et al., 2019; Kah et al., 2018), nanopesticides (Adisa et al., 2019; Jo ur
al Pr
epr
oo f
Kah, 2015), or nanoherbicides (He et al., 2019), among others. All of the above listed reviews describe general aspects about the potential use of ENMs in agriculture. However, there is a lack of emphasis on the effects of ENMs in food quality. In the present review, the readers will find a summary of the potential applications of ENMs in agricultural production, the impacts on food quality, and a discussion about the possible effects on human health.

sections.heading: 2. Nanomaterials with potential agrochemical benefits
sections.text:
This review includes literature concerning the potential reshaping of agricultural production
by replacing traditional fertilizers, pesticides, and herbicides with nano-enabled counterparts. The discussion is focused on the possible effects of ENMs in food quality. Reports on soil and foliar applications, grain and leafy plants, as well as produce are discussed.
2.1 Nanofertilizers
The US Department of Agiculture (USDA) reported a commercial fertilizer consumption
of 22 million tons in 2015 (Hellerstein et al., 2019). It is well known that traditional application of bulk inorganic salts as fertilizers results in leaching of chemicals, over-application, less efficiency, nutrient chemical transformations, and loss of nutrient availability (Achari and Kowshik, 2018). Despite environmental concerns, human health is compromised because bodies of water, including groundwater, have been contaminated from agricultural practices.
Heavy metals, such as Cd, are being released to soils through phosphate-based fertilizers
leading to the presence of this metal in fruits and vegetables. The Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry (ATSDR) lists Cd as the sixth carcinogenic substance, which endangers human health (Ulrich, 2019). Excessive nitrogen based fertilizers also contribute to nitrate accumulation and leaching to groundwaters. Drinking water contaminated with nitrate and
Jo ur
al P
epr
of
consumption of leafy vegetables result in serious health effects such as thyroid cancer, diabetes, methemoglobinemia, among others (Ahmed et al., 2017).
Soil fertility has been a research area of great interest for researchers and industries who
are making efforts to find new routes to improve crop yield and plant nutrition. Healthy soils are the basis for healthy food production worldwide. According to the USDA, one of the challenges in the 21st century is to preserve current healthy soils and restore damaged soils (Tesfahunegn and Gebru, 2020). In order to accomplish this challenge without compromising the environment, researchers and industries are focusing on technologies which offer fewer environmental disturbance and the maximum nutrient availability. Replacing traditional fertilizers with their nano-enabled counterparts can substantially improve soil health, reduce environmental pollution, and increase the effective delivery of nutrients (Shang et al., 2019).
Several reviews have been published about the use of nano fertilizers in agriculture and
their mechanisms of action. However, there is limited information about the effects of ENMs in food quality and human health (Dimkpa and Bindraban, 2018; Raliya et al., 2018; Shang et al., 2019; Adisa et al., 2019; Elemike et al., 2019). For agricultural use, ENMs are commonly synthesized by wet methods, like homogeneous precipitation, hydrogels, and micelle encapsulation, among others. The impact of ENMs sometimes depend upon surface modification, encapsulation, dopping, and composition (Raliya et al., 2018). Researches are being focused on studying nano-micronutrients uptake by plants and only few studies have reported the effect of nano-macronutrients in plant growth and fruit development (Dimkpa and Bindraban, 2018). Application or delivery systems for nano-fertilizers are the same as conventional methods: directly applied to soil, foliar application, or seed priming. Foliar application has been used extensively to increase the rate of nutrient delivery to plants; however, Jo ur na l P
r -p
ro of
formulations of ENMs most show monodispersion through leaf surface to allow the transport through the nano-pores located on the leaf cuticle. Application of ENMs directly to soil sometimes result in agglomeration by interaction with soil particles. The transport of ENMs in soils, uptake by roots, and translocation to shoots are influenced by several parameters including the type of ENM, soil composition, and the cells pore size from pit membranes (200 nm), which impede their pass/transport through the xylem (Su et al., 2019).
Table 1 shows a summary of the reported data on the use of ENMs as nanofertilizers.
Overall, the applications have been done as in traditional fertilization practices including seed priming, soil, and leaf applications. Seed priming with ENMs has been shown to increase seed germination and seedling development. The ENMs enter easily through seed coat and trigger water absorption and metabolic pathways (Shang et al., 2019). Kole et al. (2013) were among the first authors reporting an increase in fruit yield of Momordica charantia plants generated from seeds primed with nano-fullerol suspensions. These researchers found a positive correlation between fruit weight and fruit yield. Concentrations of 4.72 and 47.2 nM of fullerol resulted in a fruit yield increase of 128 and 112%, respectively. Highest content of curcubitacin-B was found in seeds treated with 10.88 nM fullerol (73.68% more than control fruits) and the lycopene content was higher in fruits from seeds exposed to 47.2 nM fullerol (81.82% more than control fruits). Seeds treated with 4.72 nM fullerol produced fruits with the highest charantin (antidiabetic) content (19.71% more than control fruits) and the highest insulin content was observed in fruits from seeds exposed to 10.88 nM of fullerol (90.91% more than control fruits) (Kole et al., 2013).
Nano-urea, nano-hydroxiapatite (nano-HAP), nano CaO, nano Mg, and nano MgO are
the most macronutrients reported to enhance plant growth and biomass production. However,
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
r of
only nano-HAP and nano-Mg have shown to increase seed yield in cowpea (Vigna unguiculata) and soybean (Glycine max). Liu and Lal (2015) reported a 32.6% growth increase and 20.4% yield increase in soybean plants grown in soil amended with 21.8 mg nano-HAP/L, compared to plants exposed to the same concentration of Ca(H2PO4)2 as P source. However, these authors did not report the nutritional content in harvested soybean seeds.
Chitosan is a natural polymer that has been used to encapsulate NKP at nano level. This
material controls the solubility and transport of NKP inside plants. Abdel-Aziz et al. (2016) synthesized a nano composite containing 500, 60, and 400 mg/kg of NKP encapsulated in chitosan ENPs. Wheat (Triticum aestivum) plants were fertilized via foliar with nano-chitosan NKP reaching the harvesting state 130 days after planting, while plants fertilized with normal NKP reached the harvesting state 170 days after planting. All parameters observed in plants grown in nano-chitosan NKP were higher compared to those observed in plants grown with normal fertilizer (root and shoot length, fresh and dry weight, water content, and leaf area, among others). The authors stated that nano-chitosan NKP stimulates vegetative and reproductive stages in wheat plants improving grain yield (26.69% higher in grain number and 101.8% grain yield/plant compared with plants grown with normal fertilizer). No analysis of the grain quality was presented.
Rui et al. (2016) investigated the use of Fe2O3 ENPs as fertilizer for peanut (Arachis
hypogaea) plants in sandy soil, which possess low nutrient holding capacity. This crop is very responsive to Fe availability in soils, particularly in the chemical form of Fe2+. The authors grew plants in soil amended with 2 -1000 mg/kg of Fe2O3 ENPs. Plants also were grown in EDTA-Fe complex at 45.87 mg/kg. Plant branch numbers, chlorophyll content, phytohormones such as abscisic acid and gibberellic acid, were higher compared to control plants in both treatments
Jo ur
na l P
r -p
ro of
(Fe2O3 NPs and EDTA-Fe complex). Fe2O3 NPs increased total Fe content in roots and shoots, compared to controls; however, direct effect of Fe products in fruit yield and nutritional status of peanut seeds were not evaluated in this research.
At this point, research related to nano fertilizers has been focused on the evaluation of the
availability of some macro and micronutrients in different chemical forms (as oxides or capped with organic substances) and their effect in several plant species. Some ENMs, containing only one or two nutrient elements, have been proven to increase the growth and development of plants, improve fruit production, increase resistance to biotic or abiotic stress, and increase chlorophyll content. A representation of general results obtained with nanofertilizers is shown in Figure 3. Future research oriented to incorporate more nutrients at nanoscale in one formulation is needed. However, combination of several elements at nano scale in one formulation may change the availability and complexation of certain nutrients in different matrices. Additionally, data on the effectiveness of formulations at nanoscale, in comparison to the bulk counterparts is needed.
2.2. Nanopesticides According to the US EPA, in 2012 the U.S. farmers expended about $56 billion in
pesticides, approximately 45% of which were herbicides, 29% insecticides, and 26% fungicides (Atwood and Paisley-Jones, 2017). Though it is difficult to have conclusive data about the environmental contamination due to pesticides, reports indicate that there are approximately 3 million people poisoned yearly by pesticides, with up to a 7.3% casualties (Bilal et al., 2019). Several strategies have been addressed to reduce the use of pesticides including traditional plant breeding techniques for pest and disease resistance. Although this technique is environmentally safe, its efficacy depends on many factors including the propagation system of the plants and the availability of resistant genotypes. Additionally, it could take several years before having desired Jo ur
na l P
r -p
ro o
materials available for mass production (Russell, 1978).
Since 1902, it is known that Bacilllus thuringiensis (Bt), originally described as B. sotto
(Milner, 1994), produces a toxic crystal that parasitize caterpillars and other larvae. About 23 years ago, maize (Zea mays L.) plants, genetically modified (GM) to resist insect attack, started to be cultivated in the United States and Canada (Pew Initiative on Food and Biotechnology, 2002). A corn variety (not specified) was genetically modified to produce the toxin naturally produced by Bt bacteria. Genetically modified corn with Bt, known as Bt corn, produces the original toxin, which is able to control lepidopterans (butterflies) like tobacco budworm (Heliothis virescens) and the European corn borer (Ostrinia nubilalis). In subsequent plant generations, Bt corn produced a series of toxins able to control coleopteran (beetles) pest like western corn rootworm (Diabrotica virgifera) and the butterfly armyworm Spodoptera frugiperda (Bravo et al., 2011). Brookes (2019) mentions that in Spain, cultivating GM insect resistant corn plants helped to reduce the use of insecticides by 678,000 kg of active ingredients in a period of 20 years, alongside saving up to 36,000 m3 water per year. Additionally, the reduction in the use of pesticides also decreased the use of fuel, resulting in an important cut of carbon emissions (Herman et al., 2019; Tsatsakis et al., 2017). The technique has generated controversies since there are some evidences pointing to an increase in tumor size of laboratory rats fed with GM maize (Tsatsakis et al., 2017). There are also concerns regarding the effects on biodiversity and the development of resistance to herbicides and insecticides.
In recent years, a new strategy that could be complementary or alternative to GM crop
plants is the use of ENMs. Engineered nanomaterials may function as active ingredient (a.i), like metal and metal oxide NMs, or they may serve as encapsulation agency like nano-chitosan. While encapsulation is aimed to control the release of a.i., some active ingredients including
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro f
metal and metal oxides, have shown to have pesticide and herbicide capabilities. Previous reviews have described the advantages of formulations containing ENMs that have proven to have pesticide properties (Adisa et al., 2019; Chhipa, 2017). Chhipa (2017) describes the pesticide properties of silver nanoparticles (NPs) against several fungi species, while Cu NPs have shown potential applications against bacteria and fungi. Other compounds such as nanosulfur and hezaconazole have also been described as potent fungicides; however, the environmental impacts of the new nanopesticides are still not well understood (Chhipa, 2017). Adisa et al. (2019) mention that polymer-based nano-enabled pesticides including nanospheres, nanocapsules, nanogels, and nanofibers are antimicrobials with different environmental persistence. Nanospheres hold the active ingredient distributed in a nanomatrix, while the polymeric matrix surrounds the active ingredient in nanocapsules (Adisa et al., 2019). The above mentioned authors highlighted the fact that different formulations of nanogels have been managed to meet organic farming standards. On the other hand, He et al. (2019), presented an analysis of the advantages of using nano-enabled technologies for the postharvest protection of agricultural products. These researchers discussed the literature concerning the use of microelement NPs such as Cu(OH)2, Cu, and ZnO, which have potential application as fungicides and bactericides.
An analysis of the data pertaining to the slow release of active ingredients through
nanoencapsulation indicates that this technique is effective in reducing the amount of active ingredient, and consequently, their environmental release and undesirable impacts (Kumar et al., 2019). Kumar et al. (2019) indicate that encapsulation of nanomaterials is of great importance. Encapsulation with clay nanomaterials have high potential due to low production cost and high biocompatibility. In the case of silica-nanoencapsulated pesticides, the biocompatibility may be
J ur
na l P
re -p
r of
improved by regulating the size of the silica shell (Kumar et al., 2019). Although it is possible that encapsulation with natural materials, such as clays, may improve the compatibility with natural environments, there is no data supporting the statement of low production costs. Adisa et al. (2019) presented a comprehensive review of ENMs used as pesticides covering up to 2018. The authors described works about ENMs including Ag, CuO/Cu/Cu2O, Cu-chitosan, ZnO, TiO2, CeO2, and MgO, among others. These nanomaterials have been tested on several fungal diseases of tomato, cucumber, watermelon, wheat, maize, and other grain plants. The ENMs were applied through roots, leaves, or seeds. In most of the cases, the reports indicate disease reductions varying from 20 to 100%. More details can be seen in Adisa et al. (2019).
Though there are many research papers aimed to demonstrate the pesticide effect of
agriculture-oriented nanomaterials (Camiletti et al., 2020; Martins et al., 2019), only a few new papers describing the nanopesticide effects of ENMs on plant-pathogen complexes were published in 2018-2020 (Table 2). For instance, (Nandhini et al., 2019) tested the efficiency of zinc oxide NPs (extracted from Eclipta alba) on the control of Downy mildew (Sclerospora graminicola) in Pearl millet (Pennisetum glaucum). They primed the seeds and made foliar applications with concentrations of ZnO NPs ranging between 50 to 500 mg/L. Authors reported that seed priming with 200 mg ZnO NPs/L produced the highest germination percentages (95%) and seedling vigor. At such a concentration, the greenhouse cultivated seedlings had the highest plant height, dry weight, and leaf surface area, compared with control. At 150 mg/L, sporulation of S. graminicola was inhibited. Seedlings sprayed with 200 mg/L of the bioproduced ZnO
ENPs, one day before inoculation, showed a 63.73% ± 3.08 protection against the mildew under
field conditions. Unfortunately, the paper does not show grain production data, which makes it difficult to evaluate the real effectiveness of the treatment. Graily Moradi et al. (2019) exposed
J ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
chitosan coated lyposome co-encapsulated imidacloprid and lambda-cyhalothrin NPs to green peach aphid (Myzus persicae). Leaves of plants of about 20-day old were treated with the nanocarriers and then exposed to aphids. Mortality of about 80% was achieved 2-8 days after treatment with 0.1 % chitosan @ 1: 2 chitosan-liposome/1:4 chitosan-lecithin. They reported that the chitosan concentration influenced the release of insecticides. Under greenhouse conditions, the pesticide persisted for 26 days, while the life cycle of M. persicae lastet about 28 days; suggesting continuous control of the bell pepper aphid. However, data was collected from controlled conditions and detached leaves. No data from entire plants and field conditions were discussed. In a greenhouse experiment, tomato plants (Solanum lycopersicum) were exposed through roots or leaves to CeO2 at 50 and 250 mg/L and transplanted into sterilized soil (Adisa et al., 2018). One week after transplantation, the soil was inoculated with 1 g/kg of Fusarium oxysporum and the plants were allowed to grow to full maturity. At 250 mg CeO2/L, the soil application reduced disease severity by 53%, while the foliar application reduced it by 57%, compared with control. The authors reported an increase on chlorophyll content in the tomato plants. The authors reported no differences in the total number of fruits in infested plants, compared with infested control. The above mentioned literature suggests potential replacement of traditional pesticides; however, there is still a long way to go to get a clear idea about products and concentrations that produce best results. Additionally, there are no studies describing the possible environmental effects or the alteration in the edible portions of treated plants. Pandey et al. (2020) sprayed four-week old tomato plants (no description of the variety) either with a peppermint oil nanoemulsion (at 1%) or 0.1% carbendazim, a chemical fungicide. Two hours later, the plants were exposed to A. solani (106 spores/mL), bagged with plastic bags for 48 h, uncovered, and allowed to grow in the greenhouse till harvesting. At 21 days, the authors Jo ur n l P re -p ro of
reported a reduction of disease severity by 87.5% and 54% with the nanoemulsion and carbendazim, respectively (Pandey et al. 2020). The authors also measured physiological parameters including chlorophyll production, stomatal conductance, photosynthesis, and transpiration. However, there was no measurement of the treatment effects on fruit production and fruit quality. The nanoemulsion seems to have better pesticide effects than the chemical fungicide; however, the comparison does not look so fair because the concentration of the fungicide was significantly lower, compared with the nanoemulsion. Although the peppermint nanoemulsion showed good effect on suppression of disease severity, there is no mean to measure the real application in agriculture, since the authors did not report the effects on fruit production and fruit quality.
2.3 Nanoherbicides More than 20 years ago, United States farmers began to cultivate GM crops that were
tolerant to herbicides (Brookes, 2014). The new approach ended up in a reduction of both the ploughing and application of selective herbicides. As a result, broad spectrum herbicides started to be used; however, as has happened with the use of new chemicals, herbicidal resistant weeds rapidly appeared (Norsworthy et al., 2012). This brought back the ancient practice of mechanic control and generated the search for new options for weed control. Perotti et al. (2019) mention that the Harrington Seed Destructor® is a technique that destroys weed seeds at harvest time, avoiding the proliferation of seeds in the next cultivation season. However, the technique is not applicable for all weeds yet (Perotti et al., 2019). Very recently, ENMs have appeared as a new option for modern agriculture. Adisa et al. (2019), summarized data on this topic that was published between 2014 and 2018 (seven articles). Data analyzed by Adisa et al. (2019) show that combinations of Ag-chitosan encapsulated, carboxymethyl-chitosan, Poly(Ɛ-caprolactone)Jo ur na l P
re -p
ro of
triazine, chitosan-imazapic/imazapyr, poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid)- atrazine have potential applications. However, no reports were discussed about the use of these combinations in agricultural fields. In 2017, Hazrati et al. (2017) reported the herbicidal activity of garden savory (Satureja hortensis) essential oil on Amaranthus retroflexus and Chenopodium album. These herbs are food plants in some regions but considered weeds in others (Grubbe and Denton, 2004). Hazrati et al. (2017) applied an oil/water nanoemulsion to the seeds of both plants and found that 800 µL/L of the nanoemulsion inhibited seed germination. Additionally, the nanoemulsion was lethal at 4000 µL/L (Hazrati et al., 2017). The use of ENMs as nanoherbicides looks promising; however, there is no knowledge on specific formulations capable of destroying the weeds without affecting the crops. Data on ENM specificity, concentrations, tolerance to adverse weather conditions, and collateral environmental effects are still missing. Moreover, there are no data on the possible physiological and biochemical effects induced in the target plants.
3. Impacts of nanomaterials in the nutritional composition of crops
3.1. Leafy plants Several leafy plants including spinach (Spinacia oleracea), lettuce (Lactuca sativa), basil
(Ocimum basilicum), oregano (Origanum vulgare), and cilantro (Coriandrum sativum) have been exposed to different ENMs. In some of these plant species, exposure to ENMs significantly increased or reduced essential metallic elements, while in others, proteins, carbohydrates, or antioxidant compounds were differentially altered.
Spinach is one of the favorite leafy vegetables in many countries. This plant has a great
nutritional value due to its high content of micronutrients and antioxidants, such as carotenoids,
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
r of
vitamin C, calcium (Ca), iron (Fe), flavonoids, and p-coumaric acid derivatives (Bergman et al., 2001; Singh and Kumar, 2020; Xu et al., 2018). Several studies have reported the impact of ENMs such as CeO2, ZnO, and FeS2 on the nutritional composition of spinach leaves. Zhang et al. (2019) exposed CeO2 ENPs (0, 0.3, and 3 mg per plant) to four-week old soil-grown spinach plants for 3 weeks. In addition to the bioaccumulation of Ce under exposure to high CeO2 concentration, the authors reported a significant decrease of Zn content (54% and 44%) and Ca content (38% and 32%) in leaves of plants exposed respectively to 0.3 and 3 mg of CeO2/plant, compared to control. At the same time, metabolomics showed that the content of amino acids including asparagine, aspartic acid, glutamine, L-cysteine, and methionine, were upregulated. On the other hand, the content of sugars including sucrose, fructose, glucose-1-phosphate, levoglucosan, ribulose-5-phosphate, allose, and xylose were downregulated under low dose of CeO2 ENMs exposure. This indicated that CeO2 trigger nitrogen and carbon pool reallocation in spinach leaf. However, there is a research question that persists, will the responses observed by Zhang et al. (2019) be repeated under other culture conditions? Kisan et al. (2015) sprayed 14- day old soil grown spinach plants with ZnO engineered nanoparticles (ENPs) (50 nm diameter) at 100-1000 mg/L and evaluated the results when the plants were 45-50 day-old. Contents of protein, fat, fiber, and carbohydrates were measured in control and ENP treated plants. The authors reported that plants sprayed with 500 and 1000 mg/L ZnO NPs had higher protein and dietary fiber content in leaves, compared with control. The highest protein content was recorded in plants exposed to 1000 mg/L. However, the authors did not present a statistical analysis of the results; consequently, it is impossible to conclude about concentration effects. Srivastava et al. (2014) primed spinach seeds with FeS2 ENPs (80 µg/mL, 14 h) and subsequently, the seeds were sown directly in the field. Treatment effects were measured when the plants were 50-day old. Jo ur na l P re -p ro of
The authors reported that leaves of plants developed from the primed seeds exhibited significant increase in leaf fresh/dry weight and in the contents of Ca (36.6%), Mn (26.4%), and Zn (58.0%), compared with control. However, no increases in Fe were observed. It is important to note that the authors used a single concentration of pyrite ENMs and there was no clear description of the type of soil.
Lettuce is another leafy plant widely grown in the temperate and subtropical regions of the
world. It is an important source of iron and provitamin A carotenoids in the human diet (Tang, 2010). It also has a large number of healthy phenolic compounds (Pérez-López et al., 2018). The effects of ENMs including TiO2, Fe3O4, CeO2, and Ag NPs on lettuce nutrient content have been studied by several researchers. Zahra et al. (2015) cultivated lettuce plants for 90 days (no description of the variety) in sandy loam soil amended with TiO2 or Fe3O4 ENMs at 50-250 mg/kg. Authors reported that both ENMs, at 150 mg/kg, increased the uptake of P in shoot and root by 74% and 89%, respectively, compared with control. Gui et al. (2015) cultivated butterhead lettuce for 30 days in soil amended with CeO2 ENPs at 50-1000 mg/kg. Results showed that CeO2 NPs, at 100 mg/kg, increased nitrate (which is a major nitrogen source for higher plants) content in leaves by 38.2%, compared with control. However, at 1000 mg CeO2 ENP/kg, there was a negative impact on the content of soluble sugar; additionally, all the concentrations tested did not impact the protein content in leaves. Unfortunately, the authors did not describe the type of soil and harvested the plants previous to reach maturity. Li et al. (2020) cultivated lettuce for 52 days in soil amended with sludge containing Ag ENPs at 10.4 mg/kg. The plants were allowed to grow until day 105, during which they were simultaneously exposed to 10 mg/L of 107Ag NPs via leaves for 3 days. The authors reported that root exposure retained the nutritional quality including protein, amino acid, and most essential element in leaves. The Jo ur na l P epr of
exceptions were K and Mg that decreased on average by 25.0 and 25.3% relative to control. The foliar exposure to 107Ag NPs significantly increased Ag in the leaves. This suggests that Ag ENPs in soil, at the concentration tested, have low risk of toxicity for lettuce. Though the authors present the chemical analysis of soil and sludge, the results of the experiment cannot be generalized because it is unknown whether the same concentration of Ag ENP would cause similar effects when soil conditions change.
Basil is a culinary herb originated in India, which is now cultivated worldwide. This herb
contains many beneficial compounds such as vitamins, minerals, and phenolic substances (Carvalho et al., 2016; Castronuovo et al., 2019). Tan et al. (2017a) monitored the impacts of TiO2 ENPs, with different surface coatings, and Cu(OH)2 nanowires on soil ground sweet basil. These authors reported a variety of responses linked to the surface coating. For instance, at 500 mg/kg, Cu and Fe were increased by unmodified TiO2 ENMs by 104% and 90%, respectively, while hydrophilic particles increased Fe by 90% and hydrophobic TiO2 increased Mn by 339%, compared with control. However, hydrophilic particles significantly reduced important nutritional elements such Ca (71%), Cu (58%), and P (40%), compared with control. On the other hand, unmodified, hydrophobic, and hydrophilic particles significantly reduced total sugar, compared with control (Tan et al., 2017b). Subsequently, Tan et al. (2018) evaluated the effects of continuous exposure to TiO2 ENMs in sweet basil. They cultivated for 65 days control seeds or seeds harvested from plants previously exposed to pristine, hydrophobic, or hydrophilic TiO2 ENPs in soil unamended or amended with 750 mg/kg of the respective particles. Elements such as Mg, Ca, and Zn were affected in different ways in roots; however, only nickel (Ni) showed important alteration in the aerial part. Plants exposed to pristine TiO2, only in second cycle, had 45% less Ni than control plants. In addition, plants exposed to pristine particles in the first cycle, Jo ur n l P re -p
ro of
unexposed or exposed to these particles in the second cycle, had 84% and 83% less Ni, respectively, than control. On the other hand, hydrophobic particles, in single or consecutive exposure reduced Ni by about 61-75%, compared with control. Moreover, hydrophobic and hydrophilic nano-TiO2 increased total sugar (186%) and reducing sugar (145%) compared to unexposed plants in both cycles. In another study, Tan et al. (2018) evaluated the response of low and high anthocyanin basil varieties (LAV and HAV) to Cu(OH)2 nanowires and bulk Cu(OH)2 (CuPro). They cultivated the plants for 45 days and sprayed 22-day old plants with 4.8 mg Cu/per pot (two plants/pot). They found that Cu(OH)2 nanowires increased the abundance of n-decanoic acid (69%), dodecanoic acid (198%), octanoic acid (61%), and nonanoic acid (90%) in LAV, but reduced n-decanoic acid (59%), dodecanoic acid (65%), octanoic aicd (34%), tetradecanoic acid (31%) as well as essential oil in eugenol (87%), 2-methylundecanal (71%) on HAV, compared with control. These researchers also found that Cu(OH)2 nanowires reduced Mn in all plant tissues of both varieties, while the bulk material, CuPro, increased chlorophyll, compared with controls. The authors concluded that the response to Cu(OH)2 was variety and compound dependent.
Oregano is a culinary herb consumed fresh/dried worldwide, mainly in South European
cuisine and Latin America (Du et al., 2018). Du et al. (2018) exposed for 60 days, soil ground oregano to metallic Cu nanoparticles (nCu) and Cu microparticles (μCu) at 0–200 mg Cu/kg soil. These researchers found that all treatments modified root and shoot Ca, Fe, Mg, Mn and decreased starch (33.9–58.5%), total sugar (39.5–55.7%), and reducing sugar (13.6–33.9%) in leaves. The highest inhibition caused by Cu ENPs was shown at 50 mg/kg and that for micro Cu was shown at the highest concentrations. It is important to point out that Du et al. (2018) used commercial potting mix (Miracle Gro®), which has a high content of organic matter. Jo rn
al P
epr
of
Experiments performed in soil with different organic matter content have shown that organic matter influences the response to ENMs exposure (Majumdar et al., 2016; Medina-Velo et al., 2017).
Cilantro is a culinary plant widely consumed worldwide. Production data indicates that
cilantro, which is consumed fresh, is abundantly produced in Mexico and the United States (Zuverza-Mena et al., 2015). Few works have described the effects of ENMs in cilantro. Morales et al. (2013) cultivated cilantro plants for 30 days in Miracle-Gro organic potting soil amended with CeO2 ENPs at 62.5-500 mg/kg. These researcher found that at 125 mg/kg, CeO2 changed the chemical environment of carbohydrates in the aerial plant parts, with differences in the area between 900 and 1200 cm-1, compared with control. Zuverza-Mena et al. (2015) cultivated cilantro for 30 days in Miracle-Gro organic potting soil amended with 20 or 80 mg/kg of seven copper products including metallic Cu and CuO ENMs. Zuverza-Mena et al. (2015), found that 20 mg Cu ENP/kg soil increased shoot Mn by 25%, while at the same concentration, CuO ENPs reduced shoot Mg by 10%. Of course, the results could be different if the plants are cultivated in other types of soil. Pullagurala et al. (2018) cultivated cilantro for 35 days in Miracle-Gro soil amended with ZnO ENPs at 0-400 mg/kg. The authors reported that ZnO, at 400 mg/kg, decreased lipid peroxidation by 70%, while at 100 mg/kg, the ENM significantly increased carotenoid content, compared with control.
Hu et al. (2019) exposed one-month old coriander seedlings to TiO2 ENMs in a hydroponic
system. The TiO2 was used at 50-400 mg/L and the plants were harvested after one week of exposure. These researchers reported that at 50 and 100 mg/L, there was a significant increase in Ca, Fe, K, Mg, Mn, and Zn. However, it is difficult to predict the results on soil cultivation from data gathered in hydroponic conditions.

sections.heading: 3.2. Grains and seeds
sections.text:
As expected, researchers have been interested in studying the interaction of ENMs with
edible grains and seeds. The most important grain and seed producing plants are wheat, rice (Oryza sativa), corn, barely (Hordeum vulgare), and bean (Phaseolus vulgaris). All of them have been exposed to ENMs. Different responses have been observed concerning the effects of ENMs in seed production and seed quality.
Wheat is a staple food cultivated worldwide that provides more than 40% of the protein
consumed by humans (Jiang et al., 2008). Effects of ZnO, Fe, CeO2, and Ag in the nutritional composition of wheat grains have been evaluated. Zhang et al. (2018) found that the foliar application of both ZnO (2 g/L) ENM and ZnSO4 (7 g/L) on field-grown wheat improved Zn concentration in grains, which was mainly present within the aleurone layer and crease of the grain, while ZnO NPs treatment also slightly increased Zn within the endosperm. However, the contents of starch, soluble sugars, and proteins in wheat grains were unchanged upon exposure to ZnO NPs or ZnSO4. Results indicated that the foliar application of ZnO NPs appears to be a promising approach for Zn bioaccumulation. By priming wheat seeds with ZnO ENPs (25, 50, 75, and 100 mg/L) and Fe NPs (5, 10, 15, and 20 mg/L) and sowing the treated seeds in soil contaminated with Cd, Rizwan et al. (2019) observed that the concentration of Zn and Fe improved but the accumulation of Cd was reduced in roots and shoots, especially in grains. This study indicated that nanoparticles have the potential to improve the nutrition in wheat plant and, at the same time, reduce the toxic effect of soil contaminants. In a greenhouse experiment, Rico et al. (2014) examined the change in the nutritional composition of wheat exposed to 125, 250, and 500 mg/kg of cerium oxide ENMs. These authors reported that at 250 mg/kg, CeO2 significantly reduced Mn and S in grains (15.5% and 6.1%, respectively), while at 125 mg/kg, Jo ur na l P re -p
ro of
altered the amino acid composition in grains, in which linolenic acid increased by 6.17% but decreased linoleic acid by 1.63%, compared to the other treatments. This study also showed that CeO2 ENPs disturbed the fatty acid synthesis and storage in grains, which could have serious implications on the nutritional value of wheat crops. Yang et al. (2018) cultivated wheat for four months in sandy loam soil amended with Ag ENPs (20- 2000 mg/kg) to monitor their impact on grain production and food quality. They found that at 200 and 2000 mg/kg, the Ag ENPs decreased the number of seeds per pot by 15.9% and 23.7%, respectively, compared with control. Additionally, at such concentration, the amount of Ag in grains was significant, compared to the other treatments. Yang et al. (2018) also reported that at 200 and 2000 mg/kg, the Ag ENPs reduced Zn (32.7 and 60%) and Cu (15.85 and 48.5%) in grains, respectively. At 20 and 200 mg/kg, there was a reduction in histidine by 5.9 and 2.9%, respectively, compared with control. While at 2000 mg/kg, aspartic acid and glutamic acids were reduced, by 8.3 and 7.9%, respectively.
Besides wheat, ENMs have also been exposed to many valuable crops used for human
nutrition including rice, corn, barely, and sorghum (Baik and Ullrich, 2008; Kean et al., 2008; Kennedy, 2002; Poornima and Rv, 2019). Rico et al. (2013) cultivated for 135 days three rice varieties (high, medium, and low amylose) in soil (Earthgro potting soil) amended with CeO2 ENM at 500 mg/kg. They found that at such concentration, CeO2 significantly reduced, in the three varieties, two essential elements (Fe and S) protein content (prolamin and glutelin), fatty acids (lauric and valeric acids), and starch. In another study, Rico et al. (2015) cultivated barley in potting soil (Miraclegro®) amended with CeO2 ENM at 125, 250, and 500 mg/kg. Results showed that CeO2 ENM, at 250 mg/kg, increased cerium (Ce) in grains by almost triple and also significantly increased the contents of P, K, Ca, Mg, S, Fe, Zn, Cu, and Al in barley. Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
Additionally, at this CeO2 concentration, grains had more methionine (617%) aspartic acid (31%), threonine (58%), tyrosine (141%), arginine (378%), and linolenic acid (2.47%), compared to the other treatments. Moreover, Poscic et al. (2016) observed the alternation of nutritional parameters of barley (Horedum vulgare L.) kernels produced by plants grown in soil amended with CeO2 or TiO2 ENMs at 0, 500 and 1000 mg/kg. The authors found that CeO2 and TiO2 ENMs had an opposite impact on nutritional quality of barley kernels. Both ENMs increased the content of most amino acids, such as lysine (51%) and proline (37%), and crude protein but reduced amylose (21%), P and S contents. However, under 1000 mg/kg1 CeO2 ENMs treatment, the B concentration was significantly lowered by approximately 62%, compared to the control. Conversely, Zn and Mn concentrations were improved by 500 mg/kg of TiO2 ENMs, while Ca by both ENMs treatments. In another study, Zhao et al. (2015) cultivated corn plants to full maturity in loamy sand soil mixed with sand (Quikrete Premium Play Sand, Atlanta, GA) and sunshine Mix #4 (SunGro Hort., Bellevue, WA) at a ratio of 1:1:3 by volume amended with CeO2 or ZnO ENMs at 400 and 800 mg/kg. These researchers did not report changes in element contraption in grains; however, they found that at 800 mg/kg, the CeO2 ENMs changed the allocation of Ca, Cu, Fe, K, Mn, and Zn in kernels. Subbaiah et al. (2016) sprayed ZnO ENMs at different concentrations (50- 2000 mg/kg) and bulk ZnSO4 of 2000 ppm on maize at two stages during tasseling (48−58 days after sowing) (DAS) and milking (100−105 DAS). The authors observed that the translocation of the Zn content was dependent on the concentration of the ZnO ENMs. The highest grain Zn content of 35.96 mg/kg dr wt was recorded with the application of 100 mg/kg of ZnO ENMs and was significantly higher over control (37%) and bulk ZnSO4 at 2000 mg/kg (29%). The authors suggest that the application of ZnO ENMs on crops, through a foliar method, could be used as a novel technology to enhance the nutrition of plants. However, Jo ur na l P re -p ro of
more studies are needed in order to correlate the content of elements in soil and the concentration of ENMs applied to the plants. Dimkpa et al. (2017) exposed sorghum (Sorghum bicolor) to Zn ENPs or salt by soil or foliar delivery under a relatively low or high level of nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium (NPK). The authors found that both Zn types increased the content of grain Zn, N, and K, irrespective of exposure pathway. However, P accumulation in plants depends on the type of Zn, Zn exposure pathway and NPK level. Grain P translocation increased significantly by ZnO ENMs under low NPK fertilization in the soil exposure, as well as in both soil and foliar exposures at the high P treatment. The research results indicate that foliar exposure is a nano-enabled strategy to improve nutrient loading of sorghum grains under Low NPK fertilization. Leguminous crops are an important source of nutrients for human beings globally. It is reported elsewhere that soybean provides vegetable oil, protein meal, and many more nutrients for an immense number of people. Peralta-Videa et al. (2014) showed that 1000 mg CeO2 ENPs kg/farm soil (organic farm Carpinteria, CA, USA) significantly decreased the content of Ca by more than 60% but increased P by 250% in soybean pods, respect to control. While at 100 mg/kg, ZnO ENPs, increased Zn by about (110%), Mn (125%), and Cu (150%) in pods. Common beans are important to the diet of many people across the world, especially in Latin America, Eastern and Southern Africa (Broughton et al., 2003). ENMs including CeO2, ZnO, and Cu-based ENMs have been exposed to common beans. Majumdar et al. (2015) cultivated to full maturity kidney bean plants in soils containing 4.2% or 10% organic matter amended with 62.5-500 mg/kg of CeO2 ENM. The plants were cultivated in a growth chamber with 14 h photoperiod, 65% relative humidity, and an illumination of 340 µmol/m2s. The authors reported that the exposure to CeO2 under high organic matter led to more changes in the nutritional quality of the bean seeds. In addition, they found that at 62.5 and 125 mg/kg, CeO2 Jo rn al re - ro f
ENMs upregulated stress-response proteins; however, phaseolin and lectins, which are associated with nutrient storage and carbohydrate metabolism, were down-regulated in a dose dependent manner by the nanoceria compound. Medina-Velo et al. (2017b) cultivated kidney beans in medium loam soil (2.8% organic matter) and organic matter enriched soil (18% organic matter) amended with uncoated nano-ZnO (Z-COTE), coated nano-ZnO (Z-COTE HP1), bulk ZnO, or ionic Zn (ZnCl2) at 0−500 mg/kg. The authors reported an interaction of the soil type with the Zn compounds; they found a 155% increase in yield in the organic matter enriched soil. The authors also reported that in organic matter enriched soil, the coated ENMs reduced seed Zn by 19%, compared to the other treatments. Medina-Velo et al. (2017b) also reported that the soil organic matter modulated the accumulation of Mn, Mo, and Ni (Figure 4). In another experiment, Medina-Velo et al. (2018) evaluated the transgenerational effects of ZnO ENMs in kidney beans. They reported no significant transgenerational effects for most of the essential elements; however, uncoated ZnO ENM at 500 mg/k and coated ZnO ENM at 125 and 500 mg/kg reduced Ni in seeds of the second generation plants by 60, 41, and 74%, respectively, compared with control. Apodaca et al. (2018) cultivated kidney bean plants for 90 days in soil (Miracle-Gro® organic potting mix) amended with bulk Cu, CuCl2, and metallic Cu ENPs at 0, 50, or 100 mg/kg, then watered the plants with 0, 10, or 100 μM of kinetin (a plant hormone) in order to study the effects of nano cupper and kinetin in kidney bean plants over their full life cycle. They found that all Cu forms, combined with 10 μM kinetin, reduced Mg from 9 -12%, while 100 mg/kg nano copper alone, decreased the accumulation of Fe by 29%, compared with control seeds. However, the variations in protein, sugar, starch content of seeds exposure to nano copper and kinetin were insignificant compared with control. The results elucidated that the combination of nano copper kinetin significantly changed the nutritional value of common beans. Jo ur na l P re -p ro of
Pea (Pisum sativum) is another leguminous plant widely consumed worldwide. Seeds of pea
plants contain almost 25% protein by weight, with amino acid profile comparable to other common legumes (Pownall et al., 2010). Ochoa et al. 2018) evaluate the nutritional components of green pea seeds cultivated in soil amended with CuO ENM at 50 or 100 mg/kg, plus IAA (indole-3-acetic acid) at 0, 10 or 100 μM. They found that at 100 mg/kg, combined with IAA at 100 μM, the CuO ENM increased Fe in seeds by 42%, while at 50 mg/kg plus IAA at 100 μM, the CuO ENM reduced B by 80%, compared to control, and by 63% respect to IAA at 100 μM. In addition, IAA at 10 μM increased seed protein by 33%. Again, the results came from a particular type of soil and under controlled conditions. More studies are needed in order to know the response to these treatments in different types of soils.

sections.heading: 3.3. Fruits
sections.text:
So far, only a few studies have shown the effects of ENMs on fruit production and fruit nu-
trient composition. Cucumber (Cucumis sativus), tomato, bell pepper (Capsicum annuum), and bitter melon are among the studied plants.
Cucumber is a garden vegetable widely consumed worldwide. The per capita consumption
of fresh cucumbers in the United States was eight pounds in 2018 (Statista, 2018). The leaf size, transpiration rate, and water demand of cucumber plant could induce the uptake ENMs, with potential effects on its fruit (Medrano et al., 2005). Zhao et al. (2013) performed a series of experiments to study the effects of ENMs in cucumber fruit. These authors conducted a lifecycle study in which cucumber plants were grown in soil amended with different concentrations of ZnO and CeO2 ENMs and measured the Zn and Ce accumulation in cucumber fruit. In a subsequent greenhouse study, Zhao et al. (2014) exposed cucumber plants to 400 and 800 mg Jo u
na l P
re -p
r f
CeO2 and ZnO ENMs per kg substrate (soil, sand, and Sunshine Mix at a ratio of 1:1:3 by volume). They found that CeO2, at 400 mg/kg, significantly increased reducing sugar by 59.6%, while at 400 mg/kg, reduced it by 64%. At 400 mg/kg, CeO2 increased globulin by 76% but reduced glutelin by 65%. On the other hand, ZnO ENMs, at 400 mg/kg, increased starch and Mn by 27% but reduced Cu by 25%, which might cause an increase in caloric value of a food that is typically characterized by its low caloric content. Again, these results are from commercial potting soil mix, data from real agricultural soil is scarce. Zhao et al. (2016), combined 1H NMR and GC-MS to detect the metabolite (nutrient supply) profile of cucumber fruit under metallic Cu ENP exposure in agricultural soils, observing that several metabolites were down-regulated including myo-inositol, methionine, citric acid, ornithine and citrulline and some sugars (xylose, fructose), amino acids (glycine, proline), organic acids (benzoic acid, glutaric acid), and fatty acids (caprylic acid, linolenic acid) were up-regulated. Cucumber plants have also been exposed to aerial application of ENMs. Hong et al. (2016) found that both CeO2 ENPs and bulk CeO2, at 200 mg/L, reduced Zn by 25%, while both CuO ENPs and bulk CuO at 200 mg/L reduced Mo in the fruit of cucumber plants, but CuO ENPs reduced Mo concentration to a greater extent.
Servin et al. (2013), cultivated cucumber for 150 days in sandy loam soil amended with
TiO2 (82% anatase and 18% rutile) ENPs at 0-750 mg/kg. FTIR analysis showed that the TiO2 treatments induce modifications in band areas of amide, lignin, and carbohydrates of cucumber fruit. Moreover, fruits from plants exposed to 500 mg/kg showed an increase in potassium (35%) and phosphorus (34%), compared with control. Alsaeedi et al. (2019) cultivated cucumber plants in soil amended with silica ENPs (100-400 mg/kg) and exposed to salinity (1.7 and 4.63 dS/min) and water stress (100, 85, and 70% evapotranspiration (ETc)). The authors report that 200 mg/kg of the Si ENPs, at 85% ETc, caused an increase of 156% in fruit yield with an increase in Na of Jo ur
na l P
re -p
r of
78%. However, the authors did not refer the results to the salinity level. Wang et al. (2019) irrigated muskmelon (Cucumis melo) plants (at seven leaves stage, no soil description) with γFe2O3 and Fe3O4 ENPs at 100-400 mg/L. The authors report that at 200 mg/L, both ENMs significantly increased fruit weight by about 9%. Additionally, they mention that at 100 mg Fe3O4/L, the fruit vitamin increased by 46.95%. Bitter melon is a cucurbit crop, which could serve as a source of both vegetable and medicine in many tropical countries (Kole et al., 2013). These authors primed seeds of bitter melon with fullerol (0.943, 4.72, 9.43, 10.88, and 47.2 nM) for 48 h, and planted them in potting mix (3B potting mix, Fafard) over a period of 85 days. They found that the accumulation of fullerol in root, stem, petiole, leaf, flower and fruit had led to the highest improvement of two anticancer phytomedicines, cucurbitacin-B by 74% and lycopene by 82% in fruits of bitter melon. Again, these results come from a specific potting soil mix, data from real agricultural soil could be different.
Tomato is widely regarded as functional and nutraceutical fruit whose production has
shown to be affected by ENMs. Lopez-Vargas et al. (2018) applied foliarly metallic Cu ENPs at 50 - 500 mg/L during the development of tomato plants and evaluated the content of the bioactive compounds in the fruit. They noticed that all treated plants had more vitamin C (from 35.5%- 122%) and more lycopene (from 57%-106%), compared with control. Barrios et al. (2017) cultivated tomato (Roma variety) for 210 days in Miracle-Gro® Organic potting mix amended with uncoated citric acid coated CeO2 ENMs at 62.5- 500 mg/kg. The authors reported that the citric acid coated ENPs at 62.5 mg/kg reduced fruit dried weight (54%), total sugar (84%), and reducing sugar (63%), while 125 mg/kg increased B by 33%. compared to control. On the other hand, uncoated CeO2, at 500 mg/kg reduced fruit B (28%), Fe (78%), Mn (33%), Jo ur na l P
re -p
ro of
and Ca (59%). However, the results could be different if the treatments are applied to other type of soil or other tomato variety.
Bell pepper is a food rich in vitamins A, C and E, and it is also a principal ingredient for
many spice products (Cisternas-Jamet et al., 2020). Rawat et al., 2018) cultivated bell pepper (California wonder 300 TMR) for 90 days in silty loam soil amended with metallic Cu ENPs, at 0- 500 mg Cu/kg. The authors showed that none of the copper treatments affected total sugar, carotenoid, chlorophyll, and vitamin C contents in the fruit. This experiment was performed in natural soil, it is possible that soil constituents interacted with the metallic Cu ENPs reducing the effects on bell pepper plants. It is also possible that bell pepper variety used in this study tolerates the Cu concentrations avoiding effects in the physiology of the plants. Li et al. (2020) cultivated chili (Capsicum annuum L.) for 67 days in soil amended by sludge with Ag ENPs at 10.4 mg/kg or without Ag NPs . Then root exposed chili continued to grow until day 75, during which they were simultaneously exposed to 107Ag NPs via leaves for 3 days. The research showed that Ag in sludge-amended soil at a level of 10.4 mg/kg did not affect the essential element concentrations (i.e., Fe, Zn, Mn, Ca, K, Mg, and P) and induced significant Ag accumulation in chili fruits. As expected, additional application through the leaves increased the Ag content in all plant parts. Data suggest that Ag NPs at 10 mg/kg, do not impact the quality of chili pepper.

sections.heading: 3.4. Roots and tubers
sections.text:
Radish (Raphanus sativus) is widely consumed around the world owing to their nutritional
content and antioxidant properties (Baenas et al., 2015). Practically, all the radish plant is eaten, principally the seedlings and tubers. Zuverza-Mena et al. (2016) germinated radish seeds in colloidal silver (Ag) suspension (125-500 mg/L) for 3 days and allowed the plantlets to growth for 5
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
days in a growth chamber (340 µmol/m2s, 25/20 ºC day/night temperature, 14 h photoperiod and 60% relative humidity). They found that sprouts exposed to 500 mg/L had less Ca (~90%), Mg (~25%), B (~50%), Cu (~60%), Mn (~50%), and Zn (~10%), compared with control. In addition, the FTIR studies showed conformational changes in lipids and proteins of the radish sprouts. This suggests that Ag ENPs could significantly impact the nutrient content of radish sprouts. Corral-Diaz et al. (2014) cultivated radish in a substrate formed with loamy sand soil plus sand (Quikrete® Premium Play Sand, Atlanta, GA), and Sunshine Mix #4 (SunGro Hort., Bellevue, WA) in a proportion of 1:1:3 amended with CeO2 ENPs at 0, 62.5, 125, 250, and 500 mg/kg. Results showed that 500 mg/kg CeO2 ENM did not affect nutrient concentration in tubers and leaves and the antioxidant capacity of radish, while 250 mg/kg nCeO2 increased the antioxidant capacity in tubers by 30%, 32%, and 85%, expressed as FRAP, ABTS, and DPPH, respectively. On the other hand, Ce accumulation in tubers of plants exposed to 500 mg/kg CeO2 had 422% more Ce than control roots. Although the data would be different if the plants were cultivated in other type of soil, Ce accumulation in tubers should be considered from a nutritional point of view.

sections.heading: 4. Possible impact to human health of nanomaterial-derived changes in the nutritional
sections.text:
composition of crops.
Data concerning the effects of ENMs in crop quality is not so abundant. Research reports
refer mostly to changes in ionome, protein, and carbohydrates modifications. Very few reports refer to essential oil components or medicinal plant-derived products. For this section, only
excess quantities are being considered since, to the authors’ consideration, deficits can be
compensated by other dietary sources to reach the Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) given by the Food and Nutrition Board of the Institute of Medicine at the National Academies of
J ur
n l P
re -p
of
Sciences, Engineering and Medicine (FNB-IM-NAS). Values on ionome changes exceeding the Tolerable Uptake Level (UL) suggested by the FNB-IM-NAS (http://nationalacademies.org/hmd/~/media/Files/Report%20Files/2019/DRI-Tables2019/4_TUILVVE.pdf?la=en) are discussed in Table 3. The UL is defined as the highest level of
nutrient daily intake that is likely to pose no risks for adults’ human health. It is important to note
that the quantities, as reported in the literature (mg/kg), do not represent a realistic amount of what is consumed. Thus, Table 3 shows all values in mg/kg reported in the literature and mg/100 g to mimic edible portions. (USDA Food Data Central cucumber; https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdcapp.html#/food-details/168409/nutrients, tomato; https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/fooddetails/475200/nutrients). Therefore, the real amount of a specific mineral that is consumed depends on fruit characteristics. Figure 5 illustrates the potential risks of excess consumption of minerals contained in plants.

sections.heading: 4.1.1. Molybdenum
sections.text:
Molybdenum is an essential metal for living organisms. In humans, it is a structural
component of molybdopterin, a cofactor required for the function of sulfide oxidase, xanthine oxidase, aldehyde oxidase and mitochondrial amidoxime reducing component (mARC). These enzymes metabolize heterocyclic compounds and sulfur containing amino acids (Beedham, 1985). According to the FNB-IM-NAS, adults need to consume at least 45 µg per day in their diet. Mo can be obtained mainly from legumes, whole grains, nuts, leafy vegetables and milk (Hunt and Meacham, 2001). A study on cucumber treated with CeO2 NPs reported Mo levels of 2.36, and 2.2 mg/kg of dry cucumber treated with 50 and 100 mg/kg CeO2 NPs. These amounts are slightly above the Mo UL of 2 mg/day (Hong et al., 2016). Like other minerals, excess Jo ur
n l P
re -p
ro of
molybdenum is excreted through urine. However, a study on high dietary intake of Mo in an area where soil has high levels of Mo showed that individuals exposed to excess Mo experienced high levels of uric acid, achy joints and gout-like symptoms (Turnlund et al., 1995). So far, it is difficult to predict if Mo concentration in cucumber fruit exposed to CeO2 ENMs is dangerous to human health.

sections.heading: 4.1.2. Magnesium
sections.text:
Magnesium is an important macronutrient with essential biological functions. It acts as a
cofactor in over 300 enzymes that regulate biochemical reactions including energy production in oxidative phosphorylation and glycolysis, protein, DNA and RNA syntheses, blood glucose regulation and muscle and nerve function. It also contributes in the transport of minerals across the cell membrane (including Ca and K); it is crucial for muscle contraction, neural communication, and heart rhythm regulation (Modern Nutrition in Health and Disease 1968).
According to the FNB-IMNAS, humans should consume around 310 and 320 mg Mg/day;
however, consuming over 350 mg/day could lead to adverse effects (Dietary Reference Intakes, 2019 http://nationalacademies.org/hmd/~/media/Files/Report%20Files/2019/DRI-Tables2019/4_TUILVVE.pdf?la=en). Hong et al. (2016) reported concentrations around 3030, 2996 and 2625 mg Mg/kg d wt cucumber after treatments with 50, 100 and 200 mg/kg of CeO2 ENPs. In addition, treatment with CuO ENPs were reported to have Mg levels of 2669.6, 2874.7 and 2681.8 mg/kg at the concentrations of 50, 100 and 200 mg/kg (Hong et al., 2016). Another study with cucumber exposed to 400 mg/kg of CeO2 and ZnO ENPs reported Mg concentrations of 393.4 and 395.6 mg/kg d wt cucumber fruit, respectively (Zhao et al., 2014). It is important to
mention that in the study performed by Hong et al. (2016), control plants had 4339.2 ± 61.8
mg/kg d wt, which could be due to the soil Mg content. The consumption of dietary Mg above
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
o f
the UL (350 mg/day) does not often pose a health risk in healthy individuals because excess amounts are eliminated via urine (Musso, 2009). However, hypermagnesemia can be caused by the consumption of Mg in its carbonate, chloride, gluconate and oxide forms. Symptoms include diarrhea accompanied by nausea and cramps (Ranade, 2001). This suggests the necessity of studying the oxidation state of Mg in ENM treated plants.

sections.heading: 4.1.3. Manganese
sections.text:
The FNB-IM-NAS states that Mn RDA for females and males are 1.8 and 2.3 mg Mn/day,
respectively. The tolerable uptake level for adults is 11 mg Mn/day. Hong et al. (2016) reported that exposure to 50 mg/kg of CeO2 ENPs resulted in 15.9 mg Mn/kg d wt cucumber fruit. In addition, fruit of cucumber plants exposed to 50 mg/kg of CuO ENPs had 13.8 mg Mn/kg d wt. Both concentrations are higher than the tolerable uptake level for Mn.
Another study was performed with basil grown for 65 days in soil amended with TiO2 ENPs
at different concentrations. Elemental analysis revealed Mn contents of 134, 176 and 128 mg/kg dry leaves when the plants were exposed to hydrophobic TiO2 ENPs at 125, 250, and 500 mg/kg, respectively (Tan et al., 2017).
Toxicity by excess dietary Mn (National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health,
NIOSH, https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/welding/default. 2013), although rare, can affect the central nervous system causing muscle spasms, tremors and loss of balance. This can progress to
locomotor deficits similar to those observed in Parkinson’s disease (Modern Nutrition in Health
and Disease, 1968). Current data does not allow a broad view about the effects of ENMs on Mn concentrations in crop plants. More ENMs, more plant species, and different types of soils have to be considered in order to have a better idea about the health risks associated to Mn toxicity and plant exposure to ENMs.
