sections.heading: 4.1.4. Iron
sections.text:
Iron is an important component of numerous enzymes including hemoglobin, which is
essential for biological processes. Iron plays a role in neurological development, physical growth, hormone synthesis, and muscle metabolism (Hurrell and Egli, 2010). Dietary iron has two forms; heme and nonheme. Plants contain nonheme Fe only (Hurrell and Egli, 2010). According to the FNB-IM-NAS, the RDA for Fe is 8 mg/day for males and 18 mg/day for females, while the UL for adults is 45 mg/day. Iron can be obtained from beans, lentils, spinach, tomatoes, and green peas, among others. Hong et al. (2016) reported that at 200 mg CeO2 ENPs/kg, cucumber fruits had 54.8 mg Fe/kg d wt. Excess intake of Fe can lead to constipation, nausea, vomiting and gastric upset (Chang et al, 2011). In severe cases it can reduce Zn absorption and lead to multisystem organ failure (Solomons, 1986). As previously mentioned,
control plants in Hong et al. (2016) study had 41.5 ± 2.2 mg/kg, which suggest that the high Fe
concentration in fruits were not only given by the ENM treatments. Additional experiments are needed for the risk assessment of the changes in the plant’s iron content due to the exposure to ENMs.

sections.heading: 4.1.5. Boron
sections.text:
Boron has a lot of functions in the human body including bone development and
regeneration, wound healing, production of sex steroids and absorption and use of Ca and Mg (Pizzorno, 2015). People in a diet scarce in fruit and vegetables are recommended to take 3 mg/d of B. According to the FNB-IM-NAS, adults tolerate up to 20 mg of B per day before it causes toxicity. Very few papers mention the effects of ENMs on B content in fruit and seeds. Barrios et al. (2017) cultivated tomato to maturity in soil amended with bare CeO NPs and citric acid
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
coated CeO2 NPs. The authors reported ~32 mg B/kg of d wt in plants exposed to 125 mg CeO2 ENP/kg soil. Studies performed on animals have shown that excess B led to reproductive and developmental defects (Dietary Reference Intakes). Composition of tomato in 2018 in the United States was 20.6 pound/person (Statista, 2019) (https://www.statista.com/statistics/257302/percapita-consumption-of-fresh-tomatoes-in-the-us/), equivalent to 26 g/person/day, which could indicate no risks due to consumption of such tomatoes exposed to 125 mg CeO2 ENPs/kg soil. However, more research is needed in order to know if ENMs increase B in other fruits/grains.

sections.heading: 4.1.6. Zinc
sections.text:
Zinc, a naturally occurring mineral can be consumed in food or as a supplement. It is
essential for the correct functioning of cellular metabolism. Around hundreds of enzymes require Zn in order to carry out their catalytic activity (Sandstead, 1994). It takes part in numerous processes including cell division, protein and DNA synthesis (Prasad, 1995), immune function and wound healing (Heyneman, 1996). The RDA for Zn is 11 mg/day for males and 8 mg/day for women (Table 4). Although the majority of Zn in the American diet is provided by red meat and poultry (USDA, 2019 https://www.nal.usda.gov/topics/food-and-human-nutrition,), Zn is obtained from seafood, nuts, beans, whole grains, and dairy products.
Data on Zn content in plants exposed to ENMs is not so abundant. Barley is one of the first
cultivated grains, now considered a major cereal grain. Rico et al. (2015) reported that at 250 mg CeO2 ENPs/kg, barley grains had 412 mg Zn/kg d wt, which is significantly higher than the UL of 40 mg/day. Similarly, Zhao et al. (2013), reported that cucumber fruit cultivated in soil amended with ZnO ENPs at 400 and 800/kg had ~103 and ~111 mg Zn/kg d wt. These amounts are more than double than the UL of 40 mg/day. Zinc related toxicity includes nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, diarrhea, and headaches (Prasad, 1995). If condition becomes chronic, other Jo ur
na l P
re -p
oo f
effects such as low Cu status, altered Fe function and reduced immune function can occur (Johnson et al., 2007). Results from Rico et al. (2015) and Zhao et al. (2013) experiments may suggest that 250 mg/kg of CeO2 and 400 mg ZnO ENPs/kg are too high for barley and cucumber, respectively, cultivated in a soils with similar properties to those used in the reported studies.
4.1.7. Phosphorus
Phosphorus is a component of teeth, bone, DNA, and RNA. It is also a constituent of cell
membranes and ATP in its phosphorus form (Calvo et al., 2015). Phosphorus is consumed through many vegetable produce including grain and seeds. Reports on P contents in plants exposed to ENMs are limited. Hong et al. (2016) reported that three-week old soil grown cucumber seedlings sprayed with CeO2 ENPs at 50 mg/L had 7499 mg P/kg dry wt fruit. Similarly, exposure to 50 mg/L of CuO ENPs resulted in 5967 mg P/kg d wt fruit, which are higher than the recommended amount 4000 mg P/day (Hunt and Meacham, 2001) (Table 4). Some studies have found that high P intake can be associated with kidney, bone, and cardiovascular adverse effects, accompanied by an increased risk of death (Menon and Ix, 2013; Chang et al., 2014). Data from the above mentioned experiments could indicate that the concentrations of ENMs used were too high for cumber plants. However, the interaction of ENM concentrations with cucumber plants may be different in other environmental conditions and other types of soils.

sections.heading: 4.1.8. Calcium
sections.text:
About 1% of the total calcium in the body is required to support critical bodily functions
including hormonal secretion, vascular contraction and vasodilation, intracellular signaling, and nerve communication (Bailey et al., 2010). The remaining Ca is stored for structure and function. As other essential elements, Ca is obtained from all sources of food including seeds, fruits, and
J ur
na l P
re -p
r of
leafy plants. Experiments have shown that ENMs can alter Ca contents in fruits.
Hong et al. (2016) reported that cucumber plants exposed to 50 mg CeO2 ENPs/kg had
4378.5 mg Ca/kg d wt, while exposure to 50 mg CuO ENPs/kg resulted in 3983.5 d wt fruit. López-Vargas et al. (2018) sprayed tomato plants with 50 mg Cu ENPs/L and found 11.7 g Ca/kg d wt (Table 4). The RDA for Ca is 1200 mg/day, while the UL is 2500 mg/day. Excessive calcium in the blood is known as hypercalcemia, which can cause vascular and soft tissue calcification, renal insufficiency and kidney stones. However, excess Ca is more likely to be caused by supplements than dietary sources (Bailey et al., 2010). Data from Hong et al. (2016) and Lopez-Vargas et al. (2018), which came from similar concentration of two ENMs, show great variability on Ca accumulation of two plant species exposed to two ENMs applied in different form. This clearly shows the need of more studies to find the concentration and exposure form of ENM capable of producing balanced element contents in fruits.

sections.heading: 4.1.9. Potassium
sections.text:
Potassium is an essential nutrient present in all body tissues. It is required for maintaining
transmembrane electrochemical gradients and fluid volume (Stone et al., 2016). According to the FNB-IM-NAS, the RDA for K is 1400 mg/day for males and 2600 mg/day for women. In the United States milk, coffee, and potatoes are the top sources of dietary potassium (Keast et al., 2013). However, fruits and grains are good sources of K as well.
Experiments with CeO2, ZnO, and Cu ENMs have shown that at certain concentration,
these ENMs alter the concentration of K in fruits. Zhao et al. (2014) reported that soil amendment with 400 and 800 mg of CeO2 or ZnO ENPs/kg resulted in 6402.8 and 5883.7 and 6022.5 and 5633.3 mg K/dry fruit, respectively. López-Vargas et al. (2018) sprayed tomato plants with Cu ENP at 500 mg/L resulting in K content of about 20 g/kg fruit, respectively. This
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
r of
suggests that the type of ENM, plant species, and exposure method may determine the effects of ENMs on K accumulation. High dietary K intake does not pose a health risk for normal kidney function. However a large dose of K can cause heart abnormalities. So far, no UL has been reported for K but there is ongoing research about its effects on heart disease risk (USDA https://www.nal.usda.gov/sites/default/files/fnic_uploads//186-268.pdf, 2019). Figure 5 shows the health risks associated with excess of nutrient elements content in plants.

sections.heading: 4.2 Changes in protein profile
sections.text:
Few researchers have studied the effects of ENMs in plant protein content. Table 4 shows
some examples of protein modifications in plants. Zhao et al. (2014) reported increments in protein content in cucumber exposed to CeO2 and ZnO ENMs (Table 4). Interesting, CeO2 at 400 mg/kg increased globulin by 43% but reduced glutelin by 35%, compared with control. On the other hand, Rico et al. (2013) reported that the amylose content modulates the effects of CeO2 ENPs on protein concentration in rice. High amylose rice showed increase in albumin ~26%); however, medium amylose showed reduction in globulin (~12%) and prolamin (~37%), compared with control. Prolamins and globulins are the main storage proteins, being globulins the predominant protein in rice. Because of their abundance, these proteins contribute essential amino acids to human nutrition (Krishnan et al, 2001; Rico et al., 2014; Rico et al., 2014; Hu and Zhou, 2014). It is difficult to predict the effects of changes in proteins on plants exposed to ENMs because the demand for aminoacids and proteins depends on each individual (WHO Technical Report, 2002). However, it is thought that a reduction in protein and aminoacids will not benefit human health. Thus, more studies are needed in order to know what ENMs are enriching/ reducing the protein content in food plants. Jo rn al Pr ep
oo f

sections.heading: 4.3 Carbohydrates alteration
sections.text:
There are no minimum requirements for carbohydrates in human diet (Ludwig et al., 2018).
However, the quality of carbohydrates plays an important role in human diet. Starch and sugars are the main carbohydrates in plants. Plants use starch as their major glucose storage system. Reports indicate that ENMs alter the content of starch and other carbohydrates in crop plants. Tan et al. (2018) exposed basil to hydrophobic and hydrophilic TiO2 ENPs and reported an increase on total sugar and reducing sugar. Hydrophobic and hydrophilic TiO2 ENPs increased total sugar (186%) and reducing sugar (145%), compared with control. Du et al. 2018 reported a decrease in starch in oregano (48.7-58.5%) when the plants were exposed to Cu ENPs (50-200 mg/kg). On the other hand, Zhao et al. (2014) reported that ZnO ENM increase starch in cucumber fruit by 36% (Table 4). A decrease in starch content is linked to low carbon uptake, which may compromise fruit sweetness (Sulpice et al. 2009). Additionally, a reduction/increase in sugar changes the calorie content in fruits, which could affect their nutritional value. Although such event does not pose any health risk for the human population, the extent of the caloric changes must be taken into consideration for a balanced diet.
Overall, the data suggest that ENMs can affect the nutritional content of crop plants.
However, the response is affected by a series of factors including the type of ENM, plant growth stage and growth conditions that modulate the interaction of plant-nanomaterial. Moreover, in order to accurately predict whether the ionome, protein, and carbohydrate variations pose a risk (and to what degree) to human health, experiments with higher organisms need to be performed. Thus, the effects on human health discussed in this paper are based on the data found in the literature.
5. Conclusions and future research needs
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
oo f
Worries about the increase in world’s population and limitations for the food safety are
changing the focus on agricultural practices. Two of the biggest pitfalls to overcome are the inefficiency in fertilization systems and the collateral damage from pesticide use. Currently, it has been underscored that nano-enabled compounds are the key to solving both drawbacks. The literature highlights the high efficiency in delivery and utilization of nutrient elements from nanofertilizers and the effectiveness of nanopesticides (White and Gardea-Torresdey, 2018). Data from several plant species and ENMs seems to corroborate the promise of nano-enabled compounds. Increments in yield, improvement in nutrient contents or medicinal products and the control of fungal diseases are some of the advantages reported so far. However, at the present time, there are more questions than answers concerning the applicability of this promising alternative. After a careful review of the available literature, it is possible to identify the following research questions:
 Nano-enabled compounds generate changes in the quality of food. Increase or decrease in
essential mineral elements, changes in carbohydrates, and increase/decrease in proteins have been reported. However, there is no evaluation of the benefits/dangers of such changes on human health. It is true that deficiencies in some essential elements such as Ni and Mo in one crop could be eased by eaten other produces. However, there could be a real problem with the consumption of produces with excess of essential elements in people whose food is vegetable-based. Additionally, stable ENMs, such as TiO2 and CeO2 have been found in nanoparticulate form in cucumber (Servin et al., 2013; Hernandez-Viezcas et al., 2013). In the case of TiO2, it has been reported that this ENM produces colon cancer in rats (Bettini et al., 2017). Figure 5 is general representation of
 Most of the results shown so far come from pot experiments with commercial potting
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro f
soil, or mixture of natural soil with sand and organic matter. Current data do not allow to predict the results under natural soil conditions. More experiments with natural soil are strongly suggested.
 Conventional fertilization techniques rest on soil analyses to recommend the type and
concentration of inorganic fertilizers. There is no idea yet how to do this for the use of ENMs as nanofertilizers.
 In the case of nanoherbicides, there is no known knowledge of doses and plant
specificity, or possible collateral effects leading to growth of tolerant species.
 There is no clear idea about the best delivery system for all the nano-enabled agricultural
products.
 In the case of nanopesticides, there are no studies about the possible development of
resistant fungal or bacterial species.
 Although great efforts are focused on the reduction of environmental impacts, most of the
nano-enabled products are metal-based and some of them have demonstrated to be very stable under certain environmental conditions. This suggests that continuous application of some nano-enabled products may result in environmental buildup of metal ions/nanoparticles with unknown environmental consequences. Studies have to be done to clarify this issue.
 Finally, benefit/cost studies highlighting the real economic improvement of the use of
nano-enabled products are needed.
As long as these questions remain unanswered, there will be low possibility of scaling up to
Jo ur

mass application of nano-enabled strategies for agricultural production.

metadata.abstractText: It is becoming more feasible to use nano-enabled agricultural products such as nanofertilizers and nanopesticides to improve the efficiency of agrochemical delivery to crop plants. Experimental results have shown that nano-agrochemicals have great potential for reducing the environmental impact of traditional agrochemicals while simultaneously significantly increasing crop production. However, emerging data suggest that nano-enabled products are not only capable of increasing yield, but also result in alterations in crop quality. Variation in proteins, sugars, starch content, as well as in metallic essential elements have been reported. Verbi gratia, albumin, globulin, and prolamin have been significantly increased in rice exposed to CeO2 engineered nanoparticles (ENPs), while CeO2, CuO, and ZnO ENPs have increased Ca, Mg, and P in several crops. Conversely, reductions in Mo and Ni have been reported in cucumber and kidney beans exposed to CeO2 and ZnO engineered nanomaterials, respectively. However, reports on specific effects in human health due to the consumption of agricultural products obtained from plants exposed to nano-agrochemicals are still missing.
